physDesc.p: M111 [The Reader]. Set 3 of 3. Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. corrections. 6 fols.
Two loose pages paginated 32 and 33, but not consecutive with the rest, on verso p. 32 is p. 185 of Between the Acts

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p: Anonymity was a great possession. It gave the early writing an impersonality, a generality. It gave us the ballds (ballads); it gave us the songs. It allowed us to know notning (nothing) of the writer; and so to concentrate upon his song. had great privilges (privileges). He was not responsible. He was not self conscious. He is not self conscious. He can borrow. He can repeat. He can say what every one feels. No ne (one) tries to stamp his own name, to disover (discover) his own expereince (experience), in his work. He keeps at a distance from the present moment. Anon the lyric poet repeats over and over again that flowers fade; that death is the ned (end). He is nver (never) tired of celebrating red roses and white breasts. The anonymous playwright has like the singer this namless (nameless) vitality, something drawn from the crowd in the penny seats and not yet dead in ourselves. We can still become anonymous and forget something that we have learnt when we read the plays to which no one has troubled to set a name.

But at asome (some) point there comes a break when anonymity withdraws. Does it come when the playwright has absorbed the contrbution (contribution) of the audience; and can return to them their own general life in indivisualised (individualised) single and separate figures? xmxmxmxmxmmmxxmxmxmx the complete [figure?] the , the There comes a mpoint (point) when the audience is no longer master of the palaywright (playwright). Yet he is not separate from them. A common life still unites them; but there are moments of seapaeation (separation). Now we say, he is
spaeking (speaking) our own thoghts (thoughts). Now thxmxmxmxmxmxmxxxx he is our slves (). But then this sense of indivi uality (individuality) comes fitfully. The beauty which is so frequent and astoinshingly (astonishingly)

The great house that deplored becomes solid and entire in the pages of Lady s diary. From childhood she was tenacious of her hereditary rights--her father had the right to carry the Kings sword "and so it lineally descnded (descended) to me./ All her youth she fought, against kinsmen, husband and the king himself for her lxmxmxx right to inherit he (her) lands in . "... I would bever (never) part from estmoreland (Westmoreland) while I lived upon any condition whatsoever" she told him. When the lands and the five castles were hers, she instantly began rebuilding; Not only the land was hers, but diamond buttons, rubies, fur cloaks. She As if to solidify
he (her) possessions she wrote out inventories of them. Family love is in part the drire ([desire? drive?]) to hand on her proprty (property). She sends for her gran (grand) children in order that they may taste the delight of possession and so refresh her own satisfaction. [The living body is robed slendidly (splendidly) in taffetas and satins. the dead body is seale (sealed) in lead to preserve it from decay.] The sense of the body permeates her pages. All movemnts (movements) become spectacular. Crowds attend her. Six bay horses darg (drag) the coah (coach). The coah (coach) is lined with grreen (green) cloth, and laced with green and black silk lace. She is for ever asserting he (her) idnetity (identity). he (She) has her initials carved even over farm hose walls. This is her property; this land is hers b (by) right. Certain flesh and blood--
xmxmxRmxmxmx.
Some speculations on the life and person of the Reader.

We can suppose that the reading public was brought into existence by two causesl when the playhouse was shut down in ; and, less definietly (defintely), when the play outgrew the theatre--when, that is, it could only be fully realised if read. In the great age of Elizabethan literature the reading public must have beenwas a small one , and composed mainly of scholars and aristocrats. The lack of general common reading is proven by the long pause, between death and the eighteenth century, when the plays of Shakepare (Shakespeare) hung suspended, unrealised. They had to wait until the printed book was held in many hands, read by many eyes in the private room before they received the other life, the detailed the
pa tciaulr (particular) life that the reader confers Again the small ness of the reading public and its special quality accounts for the scarcity of Elizabethan criticism, and the general nature of what criticism there is. It is written by writers for writers. Both in his and in are concerned with the theory of writing; not with partciular (particular) instances. They are not conscious of any curiosity on the art of the general public. The reading public is not yet asking for explanations, for instructions. The general public never read the play. They had to draw in the play as they sat or stood at t e (the) playhouse, through their

venerable institutions were being critisiced (criticised). But the public at the and the could not feel as the public in the
i9th (19th) cent ry (century) felt when was acted that old humbugs were being shown up; and the rottenness of society. After all, when country squires must call in to express their meaning, prose was not yet serviceable; the critical spirit had no proper tool.
And in fact the dramatists were not [depicting?] society. They were showing men & women themselves they were the gulf silence
So Anonymity thus lay over the

But if we cease to consider the plays separetly (separately), but
scra, ble (scramble) them together as one common attempt; then we are able to make them serve as sketches for one masterpiece. And the darkness in which these plays lie helps the endeavour to conveive (conceive) of that many nameless worjers (workers) ; and many private people were pressing their weight were discharging their emotion into that vast cauldron of seething matter which at last struck out into his plays.
the horse had a green tailâ¦ What had happened tp (to) her? When she looked out again, the flowers had vanished.

flicked on the reading lamp. The circle of readers was lit up. There in that hollow of the sun baked field were congregated the grass hopper, the ant, and the beetle, rolling pebbles of baked earth through the glistening stubble. In that rosy corner of the sun baked field, Bartholomew, and , polished and nibbled, and broke off crumbs,
"A gentleman at has seen a in his garden" Bartholomew announced.
The butterfly that looks life (like) a leaf? Lucy queried. looking up from her letter.
The newspaper dropped.
"Done?" said Giles taking it from his fathers hand.

The old man relinquished his paper. He basked, silently, in the mixed light; one hand, caressing the dog, xixlxcx rippled folds of skin towards the collar. The clock ticked; the house gave little cracks as if it were very brittle, very dry. hand on the window sill suddenly felt cold. Shadow had obliterated the garden. Roses had withdarwn (withdrawn) fxxm for the night. Mrs Swithin, folding her letter, l ant (leant) towards and said; "I looked in and saw the babies; so happy; with the paper flowers on their cots.
Giles looked up from his newspaper; Isa became a mother again, and also a wife.
In every Elizabethna (Elizabethan) play sunk beyond recall.
If xmxmxmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxm somxmxmxmxmxmxmxmx

The life The reader then is born sometime in the siteenth (sixteenth) century. But he is xmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxm but his p wer (power) of influencing the playwright is very weak in the early days. The twentiteh (twentieth) century reader that is to say, instinctivly (instinctively) tries to adapt himself to unfamiliar conditions in reading the earlier plays. He tries to supply the trumpets and the flags; the citizens and the apprentices. He substanitates (substantiates) the rather shadowy emotion that is all he can get in the plays with a dip into , with a dip into . He labours to supply the sunk parts of the play; he labours to revive the vanished cooperation between the playwright and the audience. And he is perpetually rebuffed. He cannot read the play into comlete (complete) being. He is therefore apt to become not a reader but a student, a careful collector of scattered bones. Reading is an imperfect way of bringing the early plays into existence. It is only fitfully that the readers faculty comes into play. When the dramatist becomes consc ous (conscious) of the play as a work of art; when he is able to unite the play by something in himself-- his personal ty (personality), his style, his conception it is then that he brings the reader into existence.
The life history of the reader from Elizabethan times to our own is full of obscurity. At some point his ear must have been much more acute than it is now; his sight
